But in fact we need to focus on humans, on how humans care about doing programming or operating the application of the machines. We are the masters. Install instructionsÂ below:

Ruby comes pre-installed on Mac OS X and on several Linux distributions.Â  Open up a command prompt and type:

ruby -v


If you see a version number, then Ruby is already installed on your machine.Â  Otherwise, follow the instructions below.Â 

Note that the latest stable version is 2.1, so if you wish to upgrade, you may also follow the instructions below.

You will also need a text editor at some point. There are some great options such as Textmate, Sublime Edit or Aptana (you would have this already if you participated in the HTML/CSS class).


Windows Users:
The easiest way to install Ruby on Windows is using the binary executable.

Go toÂ http://rubyinstaller.org/downloads/.

Download and run the latest Ruby executable.

Then download and set up Sublime (a free text editor if you need it)Â https://www.sublimetext.com


Mac OS X Users:
There are several ways to install Ruby on a Mac.Â  Since Ruby already comes pre-installed on OS X, it is recommended that you upgrade using Ruby Version Manager (RVM), which allows you to manage multiple versions of Ruby on the same machine.

Open a Terminal window

Install Git (if you haven't already) by typing:Â bash < <(curl -sÂ https://rvm.beginrescueend.com/install/git)

Follow the instructions atÂ https://rvm.beginrescueend.com/rvm/install/Â to install RVM

Install Ruby by typing:Â rvm install 2.1.1

To see what versions of Ruby are installed, type:Â rvm list

To use a specific version of Ruby type:Â rvm use 2.1.1 (Hint: addÂ --defaultÂ to set a default version of Ruby for new shells)

Then download Sublime and set up Sublime (a free text editorÂ if you need it):Â https://www.sublimetext.com

Alternatively, go toÂ http://www.ruby-lang.org/en/downloads/ for instructions on how to compile and install Ruby from source code.

description:
I really enjoyed the participation and energy that everyone brought to our last few meetups on Problem Validation. I hope the session was valuable to you and that you are on your way to learning from customers about the pains and gains associated with the problems they care about most.

After the sessions, I was getting the feeling that most of the audience was struggling with this fundamental question.

How do I get started with my startup?

The vast majority of the audience were what I affectionately call "Corporate Wantrapreneurs." Corporate Wantrapreneurs are working full time at someone else's company, and they are unfulfilled. They see all this startup activity around them, and they are wondering if the grass really is greener on the other side of the fence.

What if I quit my job and worked full-time on my startup idea?

Am I good enough to make my startup successful?

How much money do I need?

How much time do I need to get to profitability?

Will my partner and loved ones support my crazy idea when it isn't generating income? How much patience will he/she have to indulge my dream?

What if my business fails? Will everyone think I'm loser? Can I get my old job back? Will I beÂ homeless?

Will anyone buy my product?

Is my idea good, or bad and how can I tell?

Is this crazy or is this a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity that I need to pursue?Â 

Am IÂ delusional toÂ think this idea will work?

Session 1 of 3: How Do I Get Started With My Startup Idea?

This meetup is the first in a three part series designed to give you the tools and grit to start your startup with confidence.

In this session, I will lead a workshop to help all of you flush out your business idea. This involves defining the business concept in a way that clearly articulates the fundamental business hypotheses behind your idea. At the end of the session, you will have a clear understanding of what your idea is and what you need to do next to determine if it is real, or if it is just a crazy dream.

To that end, I propose the following agenda:

6:30 pm Networking

7:00 pm - 7:30 pm The Building Blocks Of Your Idea

- Customer segment hypothesis

- Problem hypothesis

- Value proposition hypothesis

- Business model hypothesis

- Riskiest assumption to be tested first

7:30 pm - 8:30 pm Working sessionÂ 

8:30 pm Voluntary Founder presentation

9:00 pm Go home and sleep, if you can!

Get ready for the next meetup -Â How Do I Develop The Courage Necessary To Start My Own Business?

Believe me, I've been there. I understand the thoughts and questions that are running through your mind. I've had all of those thoughts myself before you. In fact, I still have them every time I start something new. Over time, I've learned how to control my fear and anxiety instead of letting my feelings control me. Â 


Like you, I started my career in Corporate America. I worked in product development at Procter & Gamble, marketing at AT&T and Experian, and general management at Yesmail. I had success in my corporate career, but I didn't fit in. I didn't realize it at the time, but I was really an entrepreneur at heart. It turns out, my path isn't working for someone else. It's blazing my own trail. That's the only time I'm truly happy. Being a serial entrepreneur is my true path.

I look around the audience and I see myself in you. 14 years ago, I took my first steps into entrepreneurship. I boldly leaped into the scary, unknown world of living for yourself, most of the time relying on nothing more than your passion and wits. The process has been transformational for me. After I committed fully to my first startup, I knew it was the right path for me.Â And what I difficult, challenging and rewarding path it is!

Maybe your experience will be similar. Maybe you just need some encouragement and some confidence. Maybe you just need some guidance, from someone who has been there before you, and has lived through what you are about to do.

Or maybe, entrepreneurship isn't a fit for you. Maybe is just a fantasy, born out of frustration from your bullshit job. Maybe you just need a better job, or you need to make your job work for you.

One of the greatest regrets in life is being what others would want you to be, rather than being yourself.


I don't know what the answer is for you. Only you can answer this question.

All I know is this -- you owe it to yourself to find out. If you haven't found your path yet, you owe it to yourself to keep searching.Â 

FounderSensei can help you discover the truth about your startup idea, and the truth about whether pursuing it is your true path.

I'd like to host three meetups over the next few weeks where we work together to flush this out. The three sessions are focused on answering these important questions:

â€¢ How Do I Get Started With My Startup Idea?


â€¢ How Do I Develop The Courage Necessary To Start My Own Business?


â€¢ Is My Idea Good Enough To Quit My Job?

About FounderSensei

FounderSensei is for entrepreneurs who want to master the craft of creating a successful businesses from scratch. Newbies commit themselves to a new kind of apprenticeship under the guidance of a seasoned startup Sensei. Experienced entrepreneurs hone their skills and become more effective than ever. Unlike accelerators that focus on mentor dating, pitch training and demo days, FounderSensei focuses exclusively on business model validation through scientific customer experiments, resilience psychology and mastermind support. Entrepreneurs who join us will discover a proven process for finding a scalable, repeatable business model for any startup idea and the support they need to change the world. Our Sensei-Driven model will help entrepreneurs launch 1,000 startups over the next 10 years.Â 


About Dave Linhardt

Dave Linhardt is a serial entrepreneur and innovative business leader with 22 years of experience creating and growing technology businesses. As an entrepreneur, Dave has created six startups. Five were profitable without any outside capital creating millions of dollars in enterprise value.

Abstract:

Most Internet and Enterprise systems require N-9s availability, for N >= 5. These systems often have tight responsiveness requirements, too. Meeting such requirements isn't a new problem, but the requirements have grown tighter and more pervasive over time. Even systems with relatively modest requirements can benefit from the techniques used in such systems.

The Reactive Manifesto (http://reactivemanifesto.org) was created by several leaders in the fields of distributed systems and high-performance computing to codify several core traits that are universally essential for such Reactive systems. The Manifesto has been refined since it was introduced, in response to feedback from many people.

The traits are the following:

Responsive: Response times for requests are consistent, satisfying quality of service requirements. Implicit in this trait is the need to recover from errors in a timely manner.

Resilient: The system stays responsive in the presence of failure.

Elastic: The system stays responsive under various workloads.

Message Driven: The system components communicate through messages, which promotes optimal resource utilization (no blocking threads) and decoupling of components for better resiliency.

I'll describe how the four traits impact system architectures, without being overly prescriptive.
None of them is new, but many systems that claim to be reactive fall short in one or more of these areas.

We'll examine several representative examples to understand how the traits are realized in practice.

The world of Technology is always on the cutting edge of new ideas. We need to dedicate space, time, and intention in order for these new ideas to emerge. We can create conditions that will nurture the process. This is a fragile process and we can sometimes get stuck. Do you have creative project that seems to get lost and needs some direction? Thinking at the Edge is a method created by Professor Eugene Gendlin at the University of Chicago to support the development of ideas. Simple steps help us to become very articulate and precise in what we mean. At the same time we learn how to work together in ways that open up fresh pathways and bring clarity. This month, we're joined by <a></a>Samuel E. Giddins for his talk titled 'The Limits of Modularity'. More information about the talk, Samuel, and the location can be found below.

The Limits of Modularity

I advocate for modular code every day -- I even work on a few dependency managers. But there's a point where modularity becomes too much, where it can strangle your development process and sap your will to code. When your dependencies have dependencies that have dependencies, none of which are ever used elsewhere, chances are you've paralyzed yourself. You've inverted sanity in code organization -- to make any change, you need to modify the bottom-most module, but the tests that might break are in your application. This is a very real situation, and it can spiral out of hand before you realize it. So, how can you avoid this nightmare? Stop abstracting and refactoring for its own sake, and think about where functionality belongs. Down the road, when you need to apply a bug fix, it should be easy to figure out which module requires the fix, and applying it shouldn't break every level up to your application. Modularity is a tool like any other -- it has its limits, but when respected, it can deliver on its promises.


About Samuel E. Giddins

Samuel is an iOS developer at Realm, working on building modern and elegant developer tools. As a core team member of CocoaPods, RestKit, and Jazzy, Samuel has spent the past couple of years building open source tools for other developers to enjoy. About the Talk

Mining and visualizing huge databases has become a daunting task for many application domains such as astronomy, medicine, geology, oceanography, and crime prevention. In this talk, I introduce a new technique for exploring and organizing huge databases using visual features. These visual features aim to characterize the data distributions within a scatterplot (a plot of the values of variable X versus the corresponding values of variable Y).

Working directly with these measures, we located unusual correlations between pairs of variables in time series. For large datasets of thousands of dimensions, we use these measures to cluster and display only exemplars (about 30 of them) in a force-directed layout. This provides a comprehensive overview of a high-dimensional dataset. We also apply transformations toÂ reveal hidden patterns that are not apparent in the regular scatterplots. Lastly, we extend this work to handle pixels in images. During the talk, I will demonstrate my applications on real-world data such as detecting events impacting the US unemployment rates over the past 20 years or clustering half million of SETI waterfall plots.

About the Speaker

Tuan Nhon Dang

Tuan Nhon Dang is a Postdoctoral Researcher in information visualization at Electronic Visualization Laboratory, Department of Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago. He received his M.Sc. degree in Computer Science at University of Illinois at Chicago, a M.Sc. degree in Computing Systems at Politecnico di Milano, Italy in 2009 and a Ph.D. from the University of Illinois at Chicago in 2014. His research interests are in visual analytics and computer animation.

We have two hard hitting talks this month on distributed computing topics!

Multi-Language Services Using CloudI

by Bruce Kissinger


CloudI is an open-source integration cloud developed in Erlang that can be deployed publicly or privately. It supports the development of services that can be created in many different programming languages and provides scalability and fault-tolerance.Â  Bruce Kissinger will present an overview of CloudI and discuss lessons learned in porting a small application to run under the framework.

Chord Distibuted Hash Tables (DHTs) in Erlang

by Anoop Aryal

Chord is a protocol and algorithm for a peer-to-peer distributed hash table. A distributed hash table stores key-value pairs by assigning keys to different computers (known as "nodes"); a node will store the values for all the keys for which it is responsible. Chord specifies how keys are assigned to nodes, and how a node can discover the value for a given key by first locating the node responsible for that key. [1]


In this talk Anood will step you through the basics of DHTs by referencing the original Chord paper and illustrating the concepts concretely in Erlang.
